content:
The Act titled "Review Every Dollar Act of 2015" includes a limitation on the reauthorization of federal programs under Title I - Federal Program Sunset. The "Review Every Dollar Act of 2015" limits the reauthorization of federal programs to seven fiscal years. Standing committees must review direct spending programs and decide on modifications, terminations, or reauthorizations by July 31 each Congress session. SEC. 102. CRITERIA FOR REVIEW. Criteria for determining whether a program should be modified, terminated, or reauthorized include effectiveness, cost efficiency, achievement of original objectives, alternative methods, duplication or conflicts with other programs, potential benefits of consolidation, and growth in cost per beneficiary. The criteria for determining whether a program should be modified, terminated, or reauthorized include growth in cost per beneficiary, potential impacts on problems or needs, mandates on State and local governments, impediments to economic growth, and constitutionality of the program. Establishment of Discretionary Deficit Reduction Account under Title II for deficit reduction. The deficit reduction discretionary account is established by the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees. Each entry in the account corresponds to a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee and contains the deficit reduction balance. Amounts credited to the account are based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. The deficit reduction discretionary account is established by the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees. Amounts credited to the account are based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. If no statement is made, the reduction in new budget authority resulting from an amendment shall be credited to the deficit reduction balance. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget shall credit amounts of new budget authority and outlays upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill. The deficit reduction discretionary account is established by the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget shall credit amounts of new budget authority and outlays upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget of each House maintains a running tally of reductions in budget authority and outlays resulting from agreed-upon amendments. The Senate and House Budget Committees track amendments reflecting changes in budget authority in bills. Members can access this tally during bill consideration. Savings in deficit reduction accounts are calculated upon the engrossment of appropriation bills to enforce budget allocation rules. Upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the 302(b) allocation provided to the subcommittee for the bill is reduced by the amount of budget authority and outlays. The term 'appropriation bill' includes general or special appropriation bills, as well as bills for supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. SEC. 202. ESTABLISHMENT OF DIRECT SPENDING REDUCTION ACCOUNT. This section amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to create a direct spending deficit reduction account. Sec. 317 establishes the 'deficit reduction direct spending account' to be maintained by the chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The account is divided into entries for committees receiving allocations under the budget resolution, excluding the Committee on Appropriations. Each entry includes the 'first-year deficit reduction account' and the 'five-year deficit reduction account'. Entries only consist of amounts credited under subsection (c) without negative amounts. Upon the engrossment of any bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the amount of budget authority and outlays shall be counted against the allocation provided to the applicable committee. If an amendment reduces budget authority for direct spending, the Member or Senator may state the portion of the reduction achieved in the first year covered by the bill. Upon the engrossment of any bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the chairman of the Committee on the Budget shall credit amounts of new budget authority and outlays equal to the net reductions resulting from agreed-upon amendments. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget credits new budget authority and outlays equal to net reductions from agreed-upon amendments. The chairman maintains a tally of adopted amendments reflecting increases and decreases in budget authority in the bill, available to Members or Senators during bill consideration. The term 'appropriation bill' refers to any bill related to general or special appropriations, supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. SEC. 203. Conforming Amendment. The table of contents in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to include new items related to discretionary deficit reduction accounts. TITLE III - General Fund Transfers. Budget rule regarding transfers from the General Fund to the Highway Trust Fund that increase public indebtedness. TITLE IV--BUDGETING FOR ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIONS

SEC. 501. REVIEW OF RULES REQUIRING NEW BUDGET AUTHORITY. For budgetary purposes, any bill, joint resolution, amendment, or Act transferring funds from the Treasury's general fund to the Highway Trust Fund will be considered as new budget authority and outlays in the fiscal year of the transfer. Chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a new section 559a, which states that any rule for a direct spending program requiring over $100,000,000 in new budget authority for the fiscal year or the following 9 fiscal years cannot take effect without review by the Office of Management and Budget. The rule requires a determination of estimated new budget authority for the fiscal year and the following 9 years. The agency is prohibited from further action on the rule. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must review the rule annually to determine its classification. The Director determines if a rule should cease to have effect, with a transition period decided in consultation with the agency. Exceptions allow a rule to continue if deemed necessary for health or safety, enforcement of criminal laws, or national security. The Director determines if a rule should cease to have effect, with exceptions for health, safety, criminal law enforcement, and national security. Rules not reissued in similar form without specific authorization by law. Judicial review available. Definitions for 'new budget authority' and 'direct'. The Review Every Dollar Act of 2015 defines 'new budget authority' and 'direct spending'. Section 1105(a) of title 31, United States Code is amended to include a statement of the cost of projected administrative regulations. Title 5, United States Code is amended to include a new item after section 559. Title 5, United States Code is amended to include a new item after section 559a, which involves a review of rules requiring new budget authority.
